gold_sents: In response to the economic crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic of 2020, Congress passed the CARES Act, which created, among other things, the “Paycheck Protection Program.”[SENTMARKER]Under this program, small business owners could apply for a loan from the Small Business Administration; if they later certified that all of the loan funds had been used for qualifying expenses, the loan would be forgiven.[SENTMARKER]The SBA’s rules disqualified many small business owners with criminal records.[SENTMARKER]Several small business owners brought this lawsuit against the SBA in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland, challenging this criminal record exclusion.[SENTMARKER]On June 29, the court granted a preliminary injunction requiring the SBA to extend the application deadline for the named plaintiffs from June 30 to July 21, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The following week, Congress passed follow-up legislation extending the deadline for all applicants to August 8, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of July 29, 2020, further developments in the litigation are pending.

gold_sents: In June 2017, a man awaiting criminal trial and Lexington National Insurance Corporation filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that that the Criminal Justice Reform Act violated the bail provision of the Eighth Amendment, due process under the Fourteenth Amendment, and freedom from unreasonable search and seizure under the Fourth Amendment because the act favored non-monetary pre-trial release conditions over bail.[SENTMARKER]After and appeal to the Third Circuit regarding denial of preliminary injunction and a subsequent denial of certiorari in the Supreme Court, the plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 25, 2015, the plaintiffs filed a consumer class action on behalf of consumers nationwide who had been the subject of misleading and inaccurate background reports sold by the defendant, RealPage, Inc. to landlords.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), alleging that the defendant, RealPage, Inc., adopted and maintained a policy and practice of failing to timely update the criminal record information it maintained so as to eliminate records of cases that have been expunged, thus not accurately reflecting the final disposition of these cases.[SENTMARKER]Moreover, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendant systematically violated FCRA by failing to provide complete and accurate disclosures of all information the defendant maintains about consumers to these consumers upon request.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, and the defendant agreed to provide consumers additional information about federal agencies responsible for enforcing FCRA, refrain from including expunged criminal records in tenant screening reports, and disclose the names of vendors who retrieved criminal record information to consumers, plus damages.[SENTMARKER]The settlement term ended in 2020, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that a local rule which required it to agree to garnishment of judgment fees from bail bonds before it could post bail for indigent arrestees violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution and threatened its ability to operate as a non-profit.[SENTMARKER]The District Judge granted a preliminary injunction in March 2020 enjoining the County Criminal Court Clerk from garnishing fees from bonds posted by the Bail Fund.[SENTMARKER]In December 2020, the District Judge approved a consent decree where the Bail Fund and the County Government agreed to make the injunction permanent.[SENTMARKER]The matter is ongoing as the parties are litigating over who should pay attorneys fees and how much.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 5, 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund (NCBF) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee against the Honorable Howard Gentry.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Gentry violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by refusing to allow the NCBF to use its funds to bail out persons trapped in jail due to unaffordable bail amounts.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion for preliminary injunction on March 17, 2020, and issued a decree on May 22, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The decree required Gentry to stop enforcing Rule 10(B) and the surrounding policies against NCBF.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required him to provide legal advice to the mayor, the council, and all officers, departments, boards, and commissions concerning any matters arising in connection with the exercise of official powers or performance of their official duties.

gold_sents: In May of 2016 two indigent people brought a suit against the City of El Paso in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas for jailing them for failure to pay fines, despite their inability to do so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought this action under 42 U.S.C. 1983, and allege that the Defendants violated their Due Process and Equal Protection rights under the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs request declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]They want to enjoin the Defendants from enforcing their current debt collection program, which jails people who can't pay a certain portion of their fines for traffic and misdemeanor offenses.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that Defendants adopted their debt collection program to generate revenue for they city, and the individual plaintiffs were not informed that they could assert their indigence.[SENTMARKER]Rather, the Plaintiffs were simply told they had to pay or go to jail.[SENTMARKER]On January 12th, 2017 Judge David Guaderrama granted the Defendant's motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]Judge Guaderrama dismissed the Due Process claims, but did not reach the Equal Protection claims.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in January 2017, and after the Court denied two motions to dismiss filed by defendants over the course of 2017, the parties stipulated to dismissal of the action pursuant to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement agreement, defendants agreed to maintain certain administrative practices for three years.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, these practices related to notice to defendants, policies and procedures for: payment plans; notice to defendants of court hearings and schedules; and indigency hearings and warrants issued for non-payment.
pegasus_output_sents: Public-interest organization filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the City of El Paso and the Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by refusing to inform low-income debtors of their rights, and refusing to properly inquire into debtors' financial inability to pay their fines and/or the debtors' reasons for failing to pay.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court upheld the district court's denial of the preliminary injunction, finding that the plaintiffs did not suffer an informational injury that would support their claim to have Article III standing.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 2, 2003, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey against the Department of Children and Family Services (DCF) and the New Jersey Department of Social Services (DSS).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DSS was violating the federal civil rights statute by failing to provide appropriate treatment to children in its care.[SENTMARKER]The DSS filed a motion to dismiss for failure to state claim, which was granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on October 2, 2012 and the parties entered into a modified settlement agreement (MSA) in October 2012.[SENTMARKER]The MSA was designed to improve the state’s compliance with the goals, principles and outcomes of the MSA.[SENTMARKER]The MSA required DSS to provide a written case plan for each child in foster care, provide training to foster care workers, provide case management services to foster parents, and provide services to the child's foster family.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was approved and entered into by the Court in September 2003.

gold_sents: A paraplegic individual who uses a wheelchair sued Chipotle for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and California state law in two of its California restaurants.[SENTMARKER]The defendant implemented a new "Customers with Disabilities" which the district court found to be in compliance with the ADA, but the Ninth Circuit found otherwise, that viewing the ingredients behind the counter was part of the "Chipotle Experience."[SENTMARKER]Ultimately, the defendant lowered the heights of the walls in front of the food-preparation areas in all of its California locations so that customers in wheelchairs could see the ingredients, and the plaintiff was awarded $898,549 in attorneys' fees and costs and $5,000 in statutory damages.
pegasus_output_sents: Maurizio Antoninetti, a paraplegic, claimed that Chipotle’s accommodations for wheelchair-using customers wishing to enjoy the Chipotle experience violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and the California Disabled Persons Act.[SENTMARKER]He sought injunctive relief and damages under a California statute that authorizes damages for violations of the federal Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted partial summary judgment and held a bench trial.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Ninth Circuit vacated the damages award and remanded the case for a determination of the proper scope of injunctive Relief and damages.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit also vacated Judge Jones’s fees and costs award.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The plaintiff, a paraplegic who uses a wheelchair for mobility, sued Chipotle in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California for violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the high walls between the food and the customers, such that Mr. Antoninetti could not see the food while he was in line, significantly reduced his ability to enjoy the ‘Chipotle 28 Experience.’” Antoninetti, 643 F.3d at 1174.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the district court granted in part and denied in part Antoninetti’s motion for summary judgment, granting Antoninetti $5,000 in statutory damages for five “bona-fide” Chipotle visits but denying as moot the request for $3,000 in damages for three litigation-related visits.<n>The district court awarded Antoninetti $136,537.83 in attorneys’ fees for recovery of a mere $545,079.05 for his attorneys’ work in the case.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (“Amtrak”) for allegedly violating the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12131-12165, by failing to make its intercity rail stations accessible to individuals with disabilities by July 26, 2020, as required by the Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was never properly docketed or assigned to a judge, however, because the government announced its settlement with Amtrak on the same day.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Amtrak to design at least 135 accessible stations, complete construction at 90 stations, and be in the process of constructing at least 45 stations within 10 years of the settlement date.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required Amtrak to train staff on ADA compliance, establish a monitor-approved process for managing ADA complaints, and create a settlement fund to compensate individuals who were harmed by Amtrak’s most inaccessible stations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was monitored by the Federal Railroad Administration and the Department of Justice.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 31, 2018, the NAACP filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights (OCR) alleging that the OCR's March 2018 Manual violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (APA) by requiring mandatory dismissal of certain complaints and eliminating the right of complainants to appeal determinations by OCR to the Enforcement Office Director.[SENTMARKER]On November 29, 2018, the parties sought leave to file an amended complaint and a motion for a preliminary injunction to add allegations that OCR was using section 108(k) of the Manual to dismiss complaints on the basis that a similar complaint filed by another individual had been previously dismissed pursuant to section108(t).[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case without prejudice.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 8, 2006, a collection of interest groups and individuals, including the Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, Integration and Immigration Rights and Fight for Equality By Any Means Necessary, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the provisions of Proposal 2 affecting public colleges and universities violated the United States Constitution and federal statutory law.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Attorney General's Motion for Summary Judgment and dismissed the Complaint on its merits.[SENTMARKER]In its March 18, 2008 Opinion and Order, however, the District Court denied the Universities' Motion to Dismiss for misjoinder.

gold_sents: On September 29, 2011, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC") brought this lawsuit against Beverage Distributors Company, LLC ("BDC") on behalf of a visually impaired company employee in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 ("ADA").[SENTMARKER]The EEOC claimed that BDC discriminated against the employee in violation of the ADA when it conditioned his employment on the results of a medical exam and subsequently refused to hire him as a night warehouse loader upon learning that he had a disability.[SENTMARKER]The jury initially awarded the employee $132,347 in back pay, but it found that his damages should be reduced by $102,803 because he could have mitigated those damages by finding a comparable position.[SENTMARKER]On December 9, 2013, the District Court vacated these findings and awarded injunctive relief, only to be reversed by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit because of erroneous jury instructions.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit denied the EEOC's petition for rehearing in May 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in December 2015, and the matter appears to be closed.

gold_sents: On August 28, 2017, six transgender individuals currently serving in the United States military filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland Maryland contesting the President's ban on transgender service in the U.S. military.[SENTMARKER]Judge Garbis initially granted a motion for a preliminary injunction in September, but this was later stayed in 2019 when the Supreme Court issued a stay of this nationwide injunction in two factually similar cases contesting the ban.[SENTMARKER]This case changed dramatically in 2018 when the government altered its policy on transgender service in the military, eliminating an outright ban and instead putting new guidance on transgender men and women entering the service.[SENTMARKER]Judge Russell, reassigned to the case in 2018, dissolved the preliminary injunction, saying that it was only meant to stay a complete ban on transgender service in the military.[SENTMARKER]This also dismissed all claims against the 2017 outright ban as moot, and removed all plaintiffs that were already in the service and not seeking to join.[SENTMARKER]Discovery is ongoing in the case.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On August 28, 2017, the American Civil Liberties Union of Maryland (ACLU of Maryland) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Department of Defense (D.C.) and the President of the United States (President Trump) on behalf of transgender individuals currently serving in the military and those who intend to volunteer for service.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the President's ban on transgender individuals serving in military service violated the Constitution's Equal Protection Clause and the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process and Due Process Clauses.[SENTMARKER]On November 21, 2017, the District Court issued a preliminary injunction prohibiting the Defendants from taking any action to enforce the policies and directives encompassed in President Trump's August 25, 2017 Memorandum.[SENTMARKER]On January 22, 2019, the Supreme Court stayed the preliminary injunctions issued in this case and in Stockman.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit granted Plaintiffs' Motion for a Judicial Determination of Privilege Claims as moot.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted Plaintiffs’ Motion for an extension of time to file a report with the results of its study of transgender military service that reviewed evidence collected while the Open Service Directive was in place and drafted a report.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied Plaintiffs' motion for a judicial determination of privilege claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 28, 2008, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina against North Carolina State University (NCATSU) on behalf of two female employees.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that NCATSU discriminated against the female employees by failing or refusing to take appropriate action to remedy the effects of the discrimination in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree (Decree) on April 28, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The Decree was entered into with the consent of both parties, and the parties agreed to waive, for purposes of the Decree only, hearings and findings of fact and conclusions of law on all issues, and further agreed to the entry of this Decree as final and binding between them with regard to the issues raised in the Complaint.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the University/NCATSU to:  provide a written confirmation that all persons covered by the Decree attended the training;  retain all documents, in paper or electronic form (including electronic mail), that come into its possession related to complaints of sex discrimination (formal or informal, verbal or written) made by employees in the Department of Police and Public Safety; and/or (b) related to the training provided for under the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The University will offer to pay Ms. Murray and Ms. Smith a monetary award of twenty-six thousand dollars ($26,000), which will be considered compensatory damages.

gold_sents: In 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and the plaintiff-intervenor, the complainant, filed this class action lawsuit against Pitt-Ohio  Express, Inc., a transport company, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Pitt-Ohio discriminated against women by refusing to hire women as truck drivers or dockworkers, in violation of Title VII 42 U.S.C. § 2000e.[SENTMARKER]On October 1, 2008, the court approved a settlement agreement between the plaintiff-intervenor and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay $265,000 in monetary relief and  $305,000 in attorney fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]That same month, the court approved a consent decree between EEOC and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]This decree required the defendant to pay $$2,430,000 to EEOC (to be distributed to women that were affected by the defendant’s discrimination), to adopt anti-discrimination policies, to offer driver and/or dockworker positions to the women that were discriminated against, and regularly report to the EEOC to ensure compliance.[SENTMARKER]This decree had a duration of five years.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 31, 2006, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against Pitt-Ohio Express, LLC ("Pitt Ohio"), alleging that Pitt Ohio discriminated against women by failing to hire them in driver and dockworker positions in its Ohio terminals based on their gender.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that since September 1, 1997, Pitt Ohio failed to hire women as truck drivers and dockworkers because of their gender and did not hire or offer positions to other female applicants.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which Pitt Ohio agreed to correct its unlawful employment practices on the basis of sex, female, and to provide appropriate relief to Pamela Moher, and a class of females, who were adversely affected by such practices.[SENTMARKER]The decree is effective for five years.

gold_sents: Four plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and others similarly situated, filed a lawsuit against Latrobe Specialty Steel Company for violations of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA).[SENTMARKER]All four plaintiffs were over the age of fifty and were terminated following the discovery of inappropriate emails on their work email accounts.[SENTMARKER]Despite the plaintiffs' claims that the emails were a pretext for age discrimination, the court held that there was no evidence that but for their ages, the plaintiffs would not have been terminated.[SENTMARKER]Thus, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendant, which was affirmed by the appellate court.[SENTMARKER]Taxation was assessed against the plaintiffs in the amount of $21,863.88.

On August 5, 2016, Dakota Access successfully moved to intervene in support of the Corps, and Cheyenne River joined as a Plaintiff on August 10.[SENTMARKER]In light of these flaws and the “minimal” discussion of environmental justice in the EA, the Court concluded that the agency “did not properly consider the environmental-justice implications of the project” and remanded the case back to the Corps for further consideration.[SENTMARKER]The Court subsequently denied the Tribe’s request that the permits be vacated during the remand process, finding a “serious possibility” that the Corps could substantiate its decision on remand.[SENTMARKER]On February 6, 2020, the Court ordered the Corps to complete oil spill response plans, complete an internal quotation marks and citations omitted, and public reporting the project must occur.

gold_sents: This case was filed by the American Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts on May 16, 2005 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that the department's provision of more than a million dollars of public funds to a ministry called "The Silver Ring Thing" (SRT) that uses federal abstinence education funding to bring "unchurched" students to Jesus Christ constituted an unlawful establishment of religion and a governmental endorsement and preference for religion in general and specific tenets of the ministry in particular.[SENTMARKER]The ministry developed a three hour presentation that was meant to occur directly following a mandatory abstinence education assembly in public schools and which, according to the plaintiff, was "permeated with religion."[SENTMARKER]In a two-year settlement agreement entered on February 22, 2006, the defendants acknowleged that they had terminated the SRT grant effective January 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The agreement provided that defendants would not fund SRT's abstinence eduction as it had been structured and implemented during the fiscal year 2005, that strict requirements would be made before considering funding any future proposals from SRT, and that extensive monitoring of SRT's activities would occur if SRT was given a grant.

gold_sents: On May 12, 2005, individual New York residents and the New York ACORN local chapter filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Easter District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Nassau County and the Village of Garden City under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court to enjoin the defendants from proceeding with discriminatory zoning practices; to order Garden City to approve a proposed zoning that would allow for affordable housing; and to order the defendants to take all actions necessary to assure that the Social Service Site be redeveloped to maximize the availability of affordable and integrated housing.[SENTMARKER]On February 15, 2012, Judge Arthur D. United States, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down most of S.B.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction against the remaining provisions of S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 and while the parties were going through discovery disputes, the defendant filed a motion for summary judgment on March 17, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a response to the defendant's summary judgment and on September 4, 2015, the district court ruled in favor of the defendant with regard to plaintiff's claims under the Supremacy Clause, Equal Protection Clause, the Fourth Amendment, Article II, Section 8 of the Arizona Constitution, the Due Process Clause, and 42 U.S.C. §1981.[SENTMARKER]Notably, the court also entered a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on count three claim which was appealed.[SENTMARKER]Finally, on September 15, 2016, both parties conferred and filed a joint case disposition in which the plaintiff settled for $1.4 million.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2010, the plaintiffs filed suit in the District of Arizona seeking a declaration that Arizona's Senate Bill 1070 is unconstitutional in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the day labor provisions violate the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction barring the enforcement of two provisions in the law, which make it unlawful for a motor vehicle occupant to hire or attempt to hire a person for work at another location from a stopped car that impedes traffic, or for a person to be hired in such a manner.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the district court's decision in September 2011, holding that the law was not narrowly tailored to achieve the city's interest in promoting traffic flow and safety and thus violated the free speech guarantees of the First Am endment.

gold_sents: On June 8, 2015, civil detainees confined in the Tucson Sector of the U.S. Border Patrol filed a class action lawsuit, alleging violations of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment and the APA due to inhumane and punitive conditions while they were detained in holding cells.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a PI mandating that defendants must maintain conditions of confinement adequate for the detainees' physical needs and provide detainees with mats and blankets after 12 hours.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the PI order.[SENTMARKER]In 2018 the plaintiffs filed a motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of defendants' obligation to provide raised beds for detainees held for any period requiring sleep; the district court denied this motion.[SENTMARKER]After a 7-day trial in January 2020, the district court held that these extended confinement conditions violated the Constitution and issued an order enjoining the defendants from holding detainees for longer than 48 unless they provided conditions of confinement that meet basic human needs.[SENTMARKER]This permanent injunction was ordered and has been in effect since April 2020.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 25, 2017, the Center for Biological Diversity and the California Coastal Commission filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in the San Diego district court.[SENTMARKER]The Center alleged that DHS violated the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), the Coastal Zone Management Act (CZMA), and the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) by issuing waivers of applicable environmental laws to expedite construction of border barriers near San Diego and Cale, California.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted DHS summary judgment on the plaintiffs' claims.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit reversed the decision by the Fifth Circuit, holding that the district court did not have jurisdiction to consider the “predicate legal question” of whether IIRIRA authorizes the contested projects.[SENTMARKER]The panel further held that the waivers precluded the plaintiffs’ claims of environmental violations.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A group of Iranian refugees and their U.S. sponsors filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) denied their refugee resettlement applications en masse in February 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs applied for refugee resettlement through the Vienna, Austria-based Lautenberg-Specter program for Iranian religious minorities, but received mass denials with the sole explanation that they were denied "as a matter of discretion."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Lautenberg Amendment, which mandates that the denial state "to the maximum extent feasible, the reason for the denial," as well as Fifth Amendment due process and DHS's own regulations.[SENTMARKER]On July 2018, the court declared the denial notices unlawful, and ordered DHS to re-issue new notices.[SENTMARKER]As of June 3, 2020, the case is still ongoing.

gold_sents: This lawsuit was filed in response to a July 6, 2020 ICE directive that would effectively force out of the country many international students studying remotely during the 2020 coronavirus pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The University of California filed suit claiming that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act. Plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order and an order vacating and setting aside the policy.[SENTMARKER]They also sought declarative relief and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]In a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, the plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs in this case continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 6, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2020, The Regents of the University of California filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the acting director of ICE.[SENTMARKER]The Regents sought a temporary restraining order to enjoin DHS from implementing the Student and Exchange Visitor Program's (SEVP's) July 6, 2020 Directive.[SENTMARKER]The Directive announced a reversal of prior ICE policy regarding the status of international students holding F-1 nonimmigrant student visas during the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]This arbitrary, capricious, and procedurally defective agency action now forces The Regents to confront an untenable choice: to put its international students in immediate jeopardy of having to leave the country or take steps to retain them by increasing the number of in-person courses offered for Fall 2020.

gold_sents: On May 18, 2010, two organizations comprised of day laborers and/or predominately Latino immigrant workers filed a class action lawsuit in the Eastern District Court of New York under the First and Fourteenth Amendments against the Town of Oyster Bay.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU and LatinoJustice PRLDEF, sought injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees and costs, claiming that the defendants, through the passage of an ordinance prohibiting the solicitation of labor from the town's streets and sidewalks, unlawfully prohibited speech related to employment and had a discriminatory animus against predominately Latino immigrant day laborers.[SENTMARKER]After defeating the defendant's partial motion for summary judgment due to lack of standing, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment was successful.[SENTMARKER]On September 3, 2015, the District Court enjoined the ordinance and declared it unconstitutional as it violated the first amendment.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2017, the Second Circuit affirmed the District Court's decision.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court assessed attorney fees against the defendants, and the case closed later that year.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2010, two organizations that advocate on behalf of immigrant workers and day laborers commenced this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the Town of Oyster Bay.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the town's ordinance prohibiting day laborers standing near a public right-of-way from stopping or attempting to stop vehicles to solicit work, and drivers from picking up such laborers, violated their constitutional rights to free speech and equal protection of the laws.[SENTMARKER]On May 18, 2010, the district court entered a preliminary injunction on free speech grounds, barring the town from enforcing the ordinance until the hearing on the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The district court then cancelled the scheduled hearings and entered a prelim inary injunction as stipulated by the parties.[SENTMARKER]The Town then appealed to the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit upheld the preliminary injunction, but denied the defendants' request for a protective order striking the deposition of PSO Cocchi.[SENTMARKER]On June 1, 2011, the plaintiffs filed a motion to strike the defendants’ interrogatories 1-3, 5 and 7-12, and documents requests 3-7, 19, 22, 29 and 33-37, which demand identifying information of the plaintiffs’ members and/or specific day laborers known to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case without prejudice.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2009, the Town of Oyster Bay passed an ordinance prohibiting day laborers standing near a public right-of-way from stopping or attempting to stop vehicles to solicit work, and drivers from picking up such laborers.[SENTMARKER]On May 18, 2010, two organizations of day laborers sued the Town and its Supervisor in the district court, seeking to enjoin the town from enforcing the ordinance on the ground that the ordinance violated their constitutional rights to free speech and equal protection of the laws.[SENTMARKER]They immediately moved, on free-speech grounds only, for a temporary restraining order ("TRO") that would bar enforcement "until the hearing on [their]motion for preliminary injunction"<n>On October 19, 2011, the defendants issued their answer to the plaintiffs’ amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The defendants’ answer also raised the following four affirmative defenses: (1) The ordinance constitutes a reasonable time, place, and manner restriction; .[SENTMARKER](2) The ordinance does not violate the First or Fourteenth Amendments; .[SENTMARKER](3) The speech in question constitutes commercial speech, but the defendants' answer advances a substantial government interest; and (4) The ordinance is not unconstitutionally vague.

gold_sents: Sixteen states filed this lawsuit against the federal government on September 6, 2017 in response to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) memorandum issued on Sept.[SENTMARKER]5 ending Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA).[SENTMARKER]The states sought to enjoin the federal government from carrying out portions of the DHS memorandum and from using information about DACA grantees gathered in their applications to enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]While the district court granted in part the government’s motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs obtained a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2020, the Supreme Court held that DHS's decision to rescind DACA was subject to judicial review under the APA and that the rescission was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]Shortly thereafter, the Acting DHS Secretary issued a memorandum suspending DACA while DHS reviewed it.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint alleging that the Acting Secretary lacked the authority to issue the memorandum because he had not been lawfully appointed to his position.[SENTMARKER]The district court agreed.[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court vacated the memorandum and ordered DHS to resume processing DACA applications.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 6, 2017, a group of states and the District of Columbia filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York challenging the rescission of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by failing to notify certain DACA grantees of the October 5, 2017 renewal deadline.[SENTMARKER]The parties also alleged that DHS's policy regarding the use of DACA applicants' information for immigration-enforcement purposes violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction and for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit affirmed the district court's preliminary injunction in favor of the government.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In September 2017, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) announced that it would rescind the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, effective March 5, 2018 .<n>The plaintiffs filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the DHS's decision to rescind DACA was arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Fifth Circuit's rationale was therefore inapplicable.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

gold_sents: In 2018, several states filed a complaint against the Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the immigration-related conditions being placed on funding disbursed by the Department of Justice violated the Separation of Powers, the APA and the Tenth Amendment Anti-Commandeering.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, a judge granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the defendants appealed this judgment.[SENTMARKER]And later, the plaintiffs made a motion for summary judgment on the 2018 immigration-related conditions.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, a Second Circuit panel reversed the district court's order granting partial summary judgment, vacated the mandate and injunction, and remanded the case to the district court, concluding that the Attorney General was statutorily authorized to impose the challenged conditions and that the imposition of these conditions was not arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment is currently pending before the district court.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 25, 2017, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York (Edgardo Ramos) issued a judgment enjoining the Department of Justice's (DOJ) imposition of three immigration-related conditions on FY 2017 Byrne JAG funding.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff states and cities challenged the conditions on the grounds that the conditions violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court held that the Attorney General lacked the statutory authority to impose the conditions and enjoined their application.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the District Court vacated the district court's judgment and remanded the case to the District Attorney's Office for further proceedings.

gold_sents: In July 2020, several immigration advocacy and nonprofit organizations filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that by excluding “undocumented immigrants from: (a) the tabulation of the total population of the states; .[SENTMARKER](b) the calculation and statement of the whole number of persons in each state; and (c) the calculation and statement of the apportionment of the House of Representatives among the states” the federal government were violating the Enumeration and Apportionment clauses of the United States Constitution, Equal Protection under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, the Separation of Powers, the Census Act, and.[SENTMARKER]In August 2020, this case was consolidated with State of New York v. Trump.[SENTMARKER]For additional information, on this case, please see State of New York v. Trump.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 24, 2020, the New York Immigration Coalition and other plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against President Donald Trump, the Department of Commerce, and the Bureau of the Census.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the President's attempt to exclude undocumented immigrants from the 2020 Census violated Article I of the Constitution and the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 10, 2020 by Judge Jesse M. Furman, who found that the Constitution requires that all people be included in the population totals used for Congressional apportionment, regardless of citizenship status.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 28, 2020, a group of New York residents filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald Trump and the U.S. Department of Commerce (D.C.) alleging that the President's executive order on immigration was unlawful and violated the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Executive Order violated the Fourteenth Amendment's guarantee of equal protection under the law by excluding undocumented immigrants from the tabulation of total population by states and the calculation and statement of the whole number of persons in each state.[SENTMARKER]On August 4, 2020, the District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction and permanently enjoined the President from excluding illegal immigrants from counting in the population totals used for Congressional apportionment.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2008, national, state and local chambers of commerce and other nonprofit organizations advocating for their members' business interests filed a lawsuit against the State of Oklahoma, claiming that Sections 7 and 9 of the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act, which impose tax penalties on businesses that don't check the work eligibility of all of their employees in a federal database and allow discharged employees to bring discrimination suits against their employers for employing unauthorized workers, were preempted by the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs a preliminary injunction on June 4, 2008, and on appeal to the Tenth Circuit the injunction was upheld except for as to the verification requirement.[SENTMARKER]On remand to the District Court, the case was stayed pending the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Whiting, which Supreme Court later held that an Arizona law requiring employers to use E-Verify was not preempted by federal law.[SENTMARKER]Pursuant to this decision, the district court entered in a judgment on December 19th, 2012, holding that Oklahoma can require persons to contract with the State to use the employment authorization system.[SENTMARKER]However, the provision creating a cause of action for discrimination against employers who terminate an authorized employee while retaining an unauthorized employee and the provision requiring businesses to verify individual independent contractors’ authorization status and creating a withholding for work performed by individual independent contractors, were both struck down.
pegasus_output_sents: The Tulsa Chamber of Commerce and other chambers of commerce challenged the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act of 2007 (H.B.[SENTMARKER]1904) in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Act was preempted by federal law and thus unconstitutional under the Supremacy Clause.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction against the enforcement of Sections 7(B), 7(C), and 9 of the Act, and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The case was appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court upheld the district court's denial of the preliminary injunction.

gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.

gold_sents: In March of 2002, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice, acting pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA"), 42 U.S.C. § 1997 et seq., commenced an investigation into the conditions of confinement at the Santa Fe County Adult Detention Center in Santa Fe, New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ concluded that the conditions and practices at the Detention Center violated the constitutional rights of convicted inmates and pre-trial detainees.[SENTMARKER]On November 11, 2004, the DOJ and Sante Fe County entered into a Memorandum of Agreement, which detailed the agreed reforms and set forth timetables for completion.[SENTMARKER]By its terms, the Agreement was to last for a period of three years, and remedy unconstitutional practices relating to: (1) medical and mental health care; .[SENTMARKER](2) suicide prevention; .[SENTMARKER](3) protection of inmates from harm; .[SENTMARKER](4) fire safety; .[SENTMARKER](5) sanitation; and (6) inmate grievance procedures (including court access).[SENTMARKER]On November 1, 2009, after a two year extension to compel Santa Fe County to meet the benchmarks in the agreement, the DOJ allowed the terms of the agreement to expire.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ is no longer monitoring the county.

gold_sents: This was a class-action lawsuit in which the plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts had failed to provide medically necessary services as required under the federal Medicaid Act, and that it had failed to inform parents and children that they were entitled to these covered services.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Commonwealth violated provisions of the federal Medicaid Act by failing to provide home-based services to thousands of children across the state.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court approved a remedial plan intended to restructure the children’s mental health system by incorporating intensive home-based services, including behavioral health screenings, assessments, case management, crisis intervention and in-home therapeutic supports.[SENTMARKER]It also appointed a monitor to oversee implementation and compliance.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to extend the monitor’s appointment several times, with the final extension expiring on December 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to again extend the monitor’s appointment; the First Circuit overturned this ruling on May 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the extension is before the district court on remand.

pegasus_output_sents: Two individuals with disabilities filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the Florida Department of Health's practice of conditioning personal attendant care services on entrance into a nursing home violates the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, holding that the State had violated the ADA, and rejected the State's defense that inadequate funding, rather than discrimination, was the reason for retaining the plaintiffs in an institution.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the District Court's decision, but remanded for a reassessment of the State’s cost based defense.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: Two Florida residents with spinal cord injuries filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against the Florida Department of Health (DOH) and the Florida Agency for Health Care Administration (AHCA) on August 19, 2010 .<n>The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants were violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Section 504) by denying them Medicaid-funded services under the Florida Traumatic Brain Injury/Spinal Cord Injury Waiver Program (TBI/SCI Waiver) program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction to prevent the defendants from denying them the services they needed.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: Disability Rights Florida, Inc. (DRF) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida against the Agency for Persons with Disabilities (APD) and the Florida Department of Elder Affairs (AHCA) in October 2011 on behalf of individuals on the waiting list for the Florida Medicaid Developmental Disabilities Waiver program.[SENTMARKER]The P&A alleged that APD and AHCA violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by requiring the individuals to be confined unnecessarily in institutions, rather than allow them to reside in the community in order to obtain long-term care services in violation of the ADA’s integration mandate.[SENTMARKER]On July 3, 2012, the court dismissed the case on the basis of APD's standing to sue and DRF's lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement, DRF will be required to provide the APD with data on requests for services, the amounts requested, and whether each request was approved or denied.

gold_sents: On March 28, 2018, the NAACP and Prince George’s County, Maryland filed a claim against the U.S. Census Bureau and President Donald Trump for neglecting their constitutional duty to administer a fair and accurate census of the US population.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that underfunding and the flawed design of the 2020 Census might lead to undercounts of the US population in violation of the Enumeration Clause and to the detriment of minority populations, as the census count is tied to both public funding and governmental representation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs requested an injunction to require the US to develop a plan to ensure a fair and accurate count.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the claim for injunctive relief as unripe because census preparations were ongoing, but allowed the claim on underfunding to continue.[SENTMARKER]The court also allowed the plaintiffs to add two claims under the Administrative Procedure Act. On April 16, 2020, the court granted the government’s motion to dismiss; the case is closed.

gold_sents: On December 18, 2009 three young adult residents of Maine who were Medicaid recipients and who were diagnosed with cerebral palsy, filed a lawsuit against the Commissioner of the Maine Department of Health and Human Services in her official capacity.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Maine.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHHS had violated Title II of the ADA and other federal laws.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs alleged that the State had failed to accommodate Plaintiffs' disabilities and to provide medically necessary treatment in the most integrated setting possible, instead forcing them into nursing homes where they were functionally segregated from the outside world.[SENTMARKER]In August, 2010, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint reframing the case as a class action on behalf of all similarly situated Maine residents.[SENTMARKER]The parties began settlement discussions shortly thereafter.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 2012, the Court (Judge Nancy Torresen) approved the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the State to establish a Medicaid Home and Community Based Waiver (HCBW) program, which would provide a limited number of qualifying class-members the opportunity to live in community-based settings.[SENTMARKER]The case is presumably closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 22, 2014, eight same-sex couples filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan challenging the state's ban on marriage.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were married in Michigan on March 22, 2014 in accordance with Michigan law, and immediately obtained vested rights in the validity and recognition of their marriages under Michigan law.[SENTMARKER]On March 21, 2014, following a bench trial in the DeBoer case, this Court declared the Michigan Marriage Amendment and its implementing statutes unconstitutional and permanently enjoined state officials from enforcing them.[SENTMARKER]The following day, county clerks in four Michigan counties (Ingham, Muskegon, Oakland, and Washtenaw) opened their offices and began issuing marriage licenses and certificates to same-Sex couples.[SENTMARKER]The next day, on March 25, 2014, the Sixth Circuit stayed this Court’s judgment pending final disposition of the state’s appeal.

gold_sents: In 2016, states and religiously affiliated healthcare providers filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's regulation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex (which included gender identity and termination of pregnancy) violated the Administrative Procedure Act, Religious Freedom Restoration Act and constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]In October 2016, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of this regulation, which was granted on December 31, 2016.[SENTMARKER]Defendants' motion to stay the preliminary injunction was denied in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]In May 2017, the defendants filed a motion for voluntary remand and stay, arguing that HHS should be given the opportunity to reconsider the regulation at issue in this case, which would conserve the resources of both parties and the court.[SENTMARKER]In July 2017, Judge O’Connor declined to remand the case, but imposed a stay of all proceedings while HHS reconsidered the regulation.[SENTMARKER]He clarified that the December 31, 2016 preliminary injunction order would be unaffected by the stay and would remain in full force and effect throughout the stay.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the stay was lifted, and the parties resumed litigating the case.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, Judge O'Connor vacated the rule's challenged provisions.[SENTMARKER]An appeal is pending before the Fifth Circuit.

gold_sents: This case was brought, pro se, by a prisoner housed in the Special Housing Unit of New York's Attica prison, and then litigated by NY Prisoners Legal Services.[SENTMARKER]It concerned conditions of confinement in that unit, including excessive force, religion, sanitation and nutrition, access to courts, and medical and mental health care.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, piecemeal, between 1992 and 2002.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1983, inmates of Attica Correctional Facility and Green Haven Correctional Facility filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants, all state correction officials or prison authorities at Attica, had systematically violated the constitutional rights of the inmates of the Special Housing Unit (SHU), a segregated and highly restricted disciplinary prison unit.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction on January 29, 1988 and the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed the court's order in an opinion dated June 13, 1988; .<n>The defendants appealed to the Supreme Court of the United States, which remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the appeal and the case was dismissed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In August 1984, a prisoner at the Attica Correctional Facility in New York filed a lawsuit against the New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) and the Special Housing Unit (SHU) in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the SHU was failing to provide adequate mental health care and treatment to inmates.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 13, 1988.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff appealed to the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit upheld the dismissal of the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case, and the case was closed.

gold_sents: In 1997, prisoners at various facilities within the New York State Department of Corrections filed a class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Department officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Prisoners Legal Services of New York, brought the suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York, challenging the systemic deprivation of religious rights of Native American prisoners, in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In 2000, the parties reached a settlement and the court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 1997, a group of Native American inmates in New York State's prisons filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York against the New York Department of Correctional Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their constitutional rights by failing to provide or allow them to participate in sweat lodge ceremonies.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in which the defendants agreed to hire a part time minister for adherents of the Nation of Islam Faith once their numbers exceeded 200.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to allow the inmates to attend prayer services and classes with or without the presence of an outside volunteer.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 1997, a class action lawsuit was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the New York State Department of Correctional Services ("DOCS") on behalf of Native American prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments by failing to provide opportunities for Native American religious practice in Defendants' facilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in September 2000 and the case was closed in December 2000.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: Prisoners with disabilities filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the New York Department of Corrections and Community Services (DOCS) and the Deputy Commissioner/Chief Medical Officer for DOCS.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and the Eighth Amendment by failing to accommodate prisoners with disabilities in their facilities.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to certify the case as a class action.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On January 21, 2003, an Oklahoma Department of Corrections prisoner filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. §1983 in the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, alleging that his Constitutional rights under the Free Exercise Clause were being violated by the Oklahoma Department of Corrections' refusal to provide him with a Kosher diet.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated to include the complaints of two other prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The prisoners won both preliminary and permanent injunctive relief requiring the Oklahoma Department of Corrections to provide them a Kosher diet at no personal cost.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction, issued February 8, 2006, ordered the Director of the Oklahoma Department of Corrections 'to immediately provide to the plaintiffs Kosher diets at no cost, [while complying with nutritional requirements currently applicable to all other ODOC prisoners].'[SENTMARKER]On September 26, 2012 the Court found that the judgment entered in this case only applies to the claims pursued by the three named plaintiffs, and the permanent injunction relief does not apply to all Oklahoma Department of Corrections inmates.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1996, three inmates of the Colorado Department of Corrections filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado alleging a constitutional and statutory right to receive a kosher diet in violation of the First Amendment's Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]In 2002, the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals issued a decision affirming the district court's decision in Beerheide v. Suthers, 286 F.3d 1179(lOth Cir.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the decision to the United States Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]On May 16, 2003, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated and the parties agreed to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants would pay the plaintiffs no more than 25% of the additional cost of the kosher meals.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2005, a preliminary injunction was granted and the defendants were ordered to provide these plaintiffs a Kosher diet at no cost.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On January 26, 2006, three inmates of the Oklahoma Department of Corrections (ODOC) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under title 42, section 1983 of the United States Code.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the ODOC was violating their rights to freely exercise their Orthodox Jewish religion as guaranteed by the first amendment by failing to provide them with Kosher diets that complied with all nutritional requirements and standards currently applicable to the diets served to all other inmates in ODOC custody.[SENTMARKER]On February 28, 2006, the Court entered a perm anent injunction ordering the defendant, Justin Jones, to provide to the plaintiffs Kosher diets at no cost.[SENTMARKER]Nothing in the Judgment provided that it would be enforceable by all ODOC inmates.[SENTMARKER]As of January 1, 2006, the compensation rate for attorneys appointed to represent persons eligible under the Criminal Justice Act was $92.00 in non- capital cases and $163.00 in federal capital prosecutions and post-conviction proceedings.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2013, a trans woman housed in a mens prison in Oklahoma filed a pro se case against prison staff and administration in the District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]She claims that she has been denied appropriate transition related care and accommodations, amounting to a violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]Her request for a TRO and preliminary injunction were denied at the district court level, and the circuit court affirmed the denial of the preliminary injunction without comment on the TRO for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On April 3, 2015, the district court granted defendants' motion to dismiss, dismissing the claims against all defendants in their individual capacities without prejudice, and all the claims against them in their official capacity with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]Though the plaintiff objected to the dismissal, the Court denied her motion and affirmed the dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2013, a female inmate of the Oklahoma Department of Corrections filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, alleging various violations of her constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that she was denied adequate hormonal treatment, and that she received no such treatment from 1988 to 2011 or 2012.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that her official capacity claims against the director and employees of the ODOC were properly dismissed, but that her claims for injunctive relief should not be dismissed for other reasons.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed her claims against some defendants for failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted.

gold_sents: On July 27, 2012, plaintiff, a male prisoner, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Middle District of Pennsylvania under Bivens against the Federal Bureau of Prisons.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiff claimed that the defendants violated plaintiff's right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution by forcing him to share a cell with a hostile prisoner, which caused a threat of violence, and by placing him in painful restraints that caused injury for prolonged periods on multiple occasions for refusing dangerous cell assignments with hostile prisoners; and that defendants violated his right to due process under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution by depriving him of any meaningful process prior to and during their use of punitive measures against him.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2013, the U.S. District Court (Judge William B. Nealon) granted in part and denied in part defendant's motion to dismiss, declining to certify the class.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit reversed and remanded the district court's denial of class action certification on June 15, 2016, but the district court again denied certification.[SENTMARKER]Litigation is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 7, 2011, a prisoner filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania on behalf of a class of similarly situated individuals alleging that the defendants violated the Fair Debt Collections Practices Act (FDCPA) by violating the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) by failing to provide the plaintiffs with adequate notice of their debt collection practices.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied class certification, and the case was transferred to the Third Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case was later dismissed on appeal to the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit ruled in favor of the defendants.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On April 9, 2013, a prisoner at the United States Penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pennsylvania, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Bureau of Prisons.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his Fifth Amendment rights by depriving him of any meaningful process prior to and during their use of punitive measures against him.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied class certification for lack of commonality and typicality, finding that the plaintiff alleged a common threat of injury to the inmate population as a whole.[SENTMARKER]On May 23, 2016, the Sixth Circuit vacated the district court's denial of class certification and remanded the case for further proceedings.

Plaintiffs alleged that the conditions at Beaumont were unsanitary and inhumane, and that as a result of damage to the building caused by Hurricane Rita, they were subjected to confinement in a building unfit for inhabitants.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs also alleged they were entitled to damages for working conditions endured while working in a UNICOR factory manufacturing Kevlar helmets.[SENTMARKER]Defendant moved for dismissal or summary judgment in the alternate.[SENTMARKER]Several years later, but before the district court ruled, plaintiffs' counsel died, and the case was dismissed without prejudice for failure to prosecute.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2008, inmates at the Federal Correctional Complex Medium Security Institution in Beaumont, Texas, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Texas under the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) alleging that the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) breached its duty of care by failing to provide suitable quarters, safekeeping, care and subsistence in the aftermath of Hurricane Rita.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were forced to work 14 hour days, 7 days a week, and were paid only $1.00 an hour for regular time and $2.00 anhour for overtime.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 41(b) because the BOP did not breach its duties of care.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 21, 2012, a Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (TDCJ) filed this pro se federal civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]He sued multiple TDCJ employees under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that TDJC policies that prevented his smoking a prayer pipe during Native American pipe ceremonies, limited his ability to wear a religiously significant medicine bag, and prevented him from growing long hair violated his rights under RLUIPA and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]He sought declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]An additional Native American prisoner plaintiff joined the suit shortly after filing.[SENTMARKER]In February 2013, the plaintiffs amended their complaint, consented to proceedings before a Magistrate Judge, and voluntarily dismissed all of their claims except their three RLUIPA challenges against the TDCJ Director in his official capacity and their First Amendment claim seeking damages against the Program Analyst in his individual capacity.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2014, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment was granted and a final judgment entered in their favor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit and were successful in getting judgement on the RLUIPA grooming policy claim vacated and remanded.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment on the RLUIPA grooming claim was denied.[SENTMARKER]As the RLUIPA grooming policy claim moved towards trial, the initial prisoner plaintiff in the case was released and his claims were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the consolidation of cases Casey v. Davis (2:14-cv-13) and Cobb v. Morris (2:14-cv-22) with this case, as the two cases also were brought by Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit and involved RLUIPA grooming policy claims moving towards trial.[SENTMARKER]After a bench trial, Judge Ramos granted plaintiffs’ request for injunctive relief permitting them to grow their hair long, consistent with their Native American religious beliefs and entered a final judgment on February 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed, but moved to dismiss the appeal shortly after.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit granted the motion to dismiss the appeal on July 9, 2019.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.
