pegasus_output_sents: In 1985, a class of inmates at the Mecklenburg Correctional Center filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia against the Virginia Department of Corrections (VDOC).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the prisoners' rights to due process and the Eighth Amendment’s bar on cruel and unusual punishments by placing them in long-term solitary confinement indefinitely at the Red Onion and Wallens Ridge prisons.[SENTMARKER]The defendants entered into a settlement agreement with the plaintiffs in 1985 that required the defendants to permanently discontinue the Phase Program and the Special Management Unit (SMU) at Mecklenburg and to abolish the SMU.[SENTMARKER]The parties submitted the settlement agreement to the Court, which issued a consent decree on April 5, 1985.[SENTMARKER]On May 6, 2019, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, barring the defendants from imposing any further restrictions on the use of solitary confinement.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 1983, a class of prisoners held in solitary confinement at Virginia’s then maximum-security prison sued the Virginia Department of Corrections (VDOC) in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that VDOC used a so-called “Phase Program,” whereby prisoners could advance through “phases” of solitary confinement with varying levels of privileges and ultimately become eligible for return to the general prison population.[SENTMARKER]The class alleged that this program caused mental and physical harms.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in 1983 with a settlement agreement that required VDOC to abolish its long-term solitary confinement programs at Red Onion and Wallens Ridge.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with access to mental health services.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification on May 6, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, the plaintiff filed a pro se complaint in the District Court for the Western District of Virginia against the Virginia Department of Corrections alleging that their policies for beards, halal food, and television access for religious services for inmates in solitary confinement violated the Free Exercise Clause and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act. pegasus_output_sents: On September 10, 2009, a group of customers and employees of the Atlanta Eagle nightclub and Rawhide Leather filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the Atlanta Police Department and the City of Atlanta.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants conducted a warrantless raid of the Eagle on September 11, 2009 without a warrant or probable cause.[SENTMARKER]In December 2010, the parties entered into a consent order (the "2010 Order"), which required the APD to undertake a number of reforms to its police force.[SENTMARKER]The 2010 Order also required the City to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case without prejudice.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On December 8, 2009, a group of gay bar owners and employees filed a lawsuit against the City of Atlanta in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the City's police officers violated their civil rights when they unlawfully raided the Eagle and Rawhide bar in downtown Atlanta.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the City agreed to implement certain reforms to deter future instances of police misconduct, including the use of anti-gay slurs, excessive force, and search and seizure.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into on June 6, 2011, and the parties filed a motion for entry of a consent order on June 22, 2011.[SENTMARKER]On July 14, 2016, the parties agreed to a joint consent order, which required the City to implement all of the reforms set forth in Exhibit A to the settlement agreement within 180 days (i.e., before June 6, 2011) of the original complaint.[SENTMARKER]On June 22, 2016, the Court granted the parties' motion for consent order and for contempt of court, and on July 28, 2016, the court entered a final consent order.

gold_sents: In November 1974, several individuals and groups filed a civil rights action against Chicago's mayor and police officials, claiming that they had engaged in unlawful intelligence gathering and electronic surveillance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants had violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights, and they sought both damages and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]After the case was consolidated with a number of related cases, in August 1981, the parties entered into a consent decree settlement.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree barred the City from political spying, harassment, and investigation of certain activities protected by the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Despite the settlement, decades of litigation addressing enforcement of the decree followed.[SENTMARKER]In April 2011, the district court granted the City's motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The court's order permitted the plaintiffs to file a motion to reinstate the consent decree within 45 days if the City did not conduct an audit showing compliance with the terms of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]There was no further legal action taken by either party.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1974, the Alliance to End Repression and the American Civil Liberties Union filed a class action complaint against the City of Chicago, the Chicago Police Department, the U.S. Attorney General, and the Director of the FBI, alleging that the defendants were engaging in unconstitutional conduct directed at their First Amendment activities.[SENTMARKER]After several years, the case was settled in August of 1981 by the entry of a consent decree which was approved by a district judge.[SENTMARKER]The parties signed a settlement agreement in the fall of 1980.[SENTMARKER]The agreement runs to 31 pages and includes among other extraordinary provisions a section that gives standing to the plaintiffs but to every resident of Chicago at the time of the settlement to enforce the decree by application to the district court.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2004, the U.S. Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland against the Prince George's County Police Department (PGPD) alleging that the PGPD's Canine Section had engaged in a pattern or practice of excessive force.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree, which was entered into on March 11, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The Consent Decree prohibited the use of choke holds and similar carotid holds in those instances where deadly force is authorized.[SENTMARKER]The PGPD and the Office of the County Attorney proposed to insert language into its Use of Force Policies, specifically prohibiting choke holds, carotid holds, and other choke holds.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was approved by the Court and entered into three years later.[SENTMARKER]The Court entered an Order of the Consent Decree on March 12, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties have continued to monitor the Defendants’ progress towards compliance with the consent decree.

gold_sents: In 2011 voters in Wisconsin filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their fundamental right to vote had been violated by Act 23, Wisconsin's law implementing a voter ID requirement.[SENTMARKER]After much litigation, in 2016 a judge granted a preliminary injunction allowing voters without IDs to sign an affidavit in place of the ID requirement for the 2016 presidential election.[SENTMARKER]The state appealed the injunction to the Seventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit stayed the injunction pending the appeal.[SENTMARKER]As of December 2019, the appeal remained pending in the Seventh Circuit.

gold_sents: On June 20, 1989, foster care children of the District of Columbia filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Children's Rights and the ACLU, asked the court to order improved policies related to protective services, family preservation and preventive services, child placement, case reviews, adoptions, and staffing, among other issues, claiming violations of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 (AACWA), the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, the District of Columbia Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977, the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, and the District of Columbia Youth Residential Facilities Licensor Act of 1986.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that caseloads were too large, leaving many children in the foster care system for far too long with unresolved cases.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the complaint alleged inappropriate placements for children and inadequate efforts to return children home.[SENTMARKER]In 1993, Judge Thomas F. Hogan approved a consent decree directing DHS to develop policies and procedures to rectify the system.[SENTMARKER]After many years of oversight, and periodic contempt orders, the system has gradually improved.[SENTMARKER]However, there is still a monitor in place reporting on the progress of the Child and Family Services Agency (CFSA) created as a result of this case.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1993, a group of children brought a class action suit in the District of Columbia alleging that the District's foster care system was inadequate and that the children were being abused or neglected.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a consent decree, which the plaintiffs moved to enforce two years later, arguing that state officials failed to fully comply with its requirements.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit reversed, concluding that the district court lacked jurisdiction under the Eleventh Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The District appealed, contending that the consent decree violated the Fifth Amendment, and the Supreme Court denied its petition for writ of certiorari.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In September 1988, the Center for the Study of Social Policy with the Office of the Mayor and the Child and Family Services Agency of the District of Columbia filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the district of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the District operated its child welfare system in violation of the federal Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 and Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, as well as the fifth amendment to the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the District to develop policies and procedures for the reporting of reports of neglect/abuse, establish placement support services sufficient to assure placement for children, and provide a listing of all children who have been in emergency care for more than 21 days.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the district had violated its own statutes and the consent decree was not consistent with the district's compliance with the terms of the decree.

gold_sents: On April 29, four individuals with disabilities and Disability Rights New York filed a complaint against Andrew Cuomo, the Governor of New York State.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the absence of live televised American Sign Language (ASL) interpretation in Governor Cuomo’s daily televised briefings on COVID-19 discriminated against populations with disabilities residing in New York by failing to provide a live ASL interpreter.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, declaring the lack of ASL interpretation as a violation under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO and preliminary injunction requiring the defendant to immediately include live in-frame ASL interpretation for all briefings addressed to New York residents.[SENTMARKER]The preliminary injunction was granted on May 11, and the defendant was ordered to immediately implement live, in-frame ASL interpretation for his daily press briefings.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2020, Disability Rights New York (DRNY) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against New York County and Governor Andrew Cuomo.[SENTMARKER]DRNY alleged that the county violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Minnesota Human Rights Act (HRA) by failing to provide an in-frame American Sign Language (ASL) interpreter during televised broadcast briefings.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted DRNY's motion for a preliminary injunction on May 11, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit affirmed the district court's grant of summary judgment for the county, holding in part that the ADA and Rehab Act did not require the county to provided an ASL interpreter at every meeting held to discuss emergency decontamination in the plaintiffs' community.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 24, 2020, Disability Rights New York (DRNY) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against New York Governor Andrew Cuomo.[SENTMARKER]DRNY argued that Governor Cuomo's failure to provide live in-frame ASL interpretation during his daily press briefings violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (RA).[SENTMARKER]On May 11, 2020, the Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction requiring Governor Cuomo to provide an in- frame ASL interpreter during his televised press briefings.[SENTMARKER]On May 13, 2020, the Governor was ordered to submit a detailed affidavit explaining why and providing a date by which it will be implemented.

gold_sents: On April 8, 2014, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island alleging that Rhode Island violated the ADA by segregating individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities in sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs that denied them the opportunity to associate with those who did not have a disability.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2014, the District Court approved a Consent Decree where Rhode Island agreed to, among other things, provide employment planning services to individuals with developmental and intellectual disabilities designed to encourage and assist them in working in integrated working environments, provide state support and services for those working in integrated settings and those making the transition to those settings, programs to educate relevant individuals about the programs and benefits that the Rhode Island offers to those working in integrated settings.[SENTMARKER]Rhode Island must also implement policies regarding the services required by the Consent Decree, train its personnel in the new procedures and working with individuals with disabilities, and Rhode Island must help sheltered workshops change their structure to become integrated working environments.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 11, 2013, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) sued the State of Rhode Island and the City of Providence for violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Supreme Court's decision in Olmstead v. L.C.[SENTMARKER]by failing to serve individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) in the most integrated day activity service setting appropriate for their needs, and by placing transition-age youth at serious risk of segregation.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought in the United States District Court for the District of Providence.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree to resolve the case.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered into on September 24, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a system of employment and integrated day services for individuals with I/DD in the Rhode Island Department of Education (RIDE), the Office of Rehabilitative Services (ORS), and the Providence Public Schools Department (PPSD) between January 1, 2015 and September 30, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The Court Monitor reported that the State was not in full compliance with the terms of the consent decree and that additional steps needed to be taken to fully comply with its terms and conditions.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On April 9, 2014, the Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division and the Rhode Island Department of Education filed this Consent Decree in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island.[SENTMARKER]The Consent Decree was designed to change the nature and operation of day and employment services furnished to individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) who receive publicly financed supports.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the Consent Decree required the State to transform its service system to provide individuals with IDD the training and support they need to become employed in competitive, integrated jobs working alongside people without disabilities and paid a minimum wage or higher.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to implement an effective plan to transition individuals unnecessarily segregated in sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs to integrated employment and day settings in the community.[SENTMARKER]The plan should include requirements for effective outreach and in-reach, transition, discovery and vocational and situational assessment for service recipients and their families.

gold_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles brought this suit against the U.S. Attorney General and  Secretary of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs challenged the federal immigration rule restricting eligibility for asylum for noncitizens who transited through another country prior to reaching the southern U.S. border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs successfully sought a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]However, defendants appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit and the nationwide scope of the injunction was stayed.[SENTMARKER]Then the District Court restored the nationwide scope of the injunction on September 9, 2019, but the government again appealed and the U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay pending disposition of the appeal in the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a separate preliminary injunction against another rule issued by the Department of Homeland Security in the closing days of the Trump Administration which was substantially similar to the one already enjoined.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the original injunction in April, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing but is likely to terminate soon given the change in presidential administrations.

gold_sents: This is a class action lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a South Carolina immigration law which requires state and local law enforcement officers to investigate the immigration status of any individual they stop, detain, or arrest whenever they have a "reasonable suspicion" that the individual lacks immigration status, allows law enforcement officers to arrest individuals solely for failing to carry registration documents, makes it a crime to harbor or transport an undocumented immigrant or to be harbored or transported by others if one is an undocumented immigrant, and imposes civil liability on the police for failing to enforce its provisions to the maximum extent possible.[SENTMARKER]The law was patterned after Arizona's SB 1070.[SENTMARKER]The District Court has issued a preliminary injunction barring enforcement of the law, and this injunction has been appealed to the Fourth Circuit; in the meantime, the case, along with several others like it from different states, are stayed at the District Court or U.S.[SENTMARKER]Appellate level pending the decision of the Supreme Court in United States v. Arizona.[SENTMARKER]After Arizona v. United States was decided the issue was remanded to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The district court left in place most of its original preliminary injunction, enjoining the state from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6 (B)(2).[SENTMARKER]The 4th Circuit per Judge Davis agreed and affirmed the order on July 13, 2013.[SENTMARKER]In March of 2014 Judge Gergel permanently enjoined South Carolina from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6(B)(2).[SENTMARKER]Furthermore the state agreed to more favorable interpretations of Section 7, and the remainder of Section, encouraging the Plaintiffs to dismiss their claims on those sections without prejudice.

gold_sents: In July 2008, the plaintiffs sued the City of Tenaha under the Fourth Amendment (unreasonable search and seizure) and the Fourteenth Amendment (equal protection).[SENTMARKER]They claimed that law enforcement officials in and around the City of Tenaha have developed an illegal practice of targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from people who appeared to be non-white or who were traveling with non-white passengers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that they had been victims of such stops and seizures of amounts up to $50,000, as well as false prosecution or detention.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement in August 2012.[SENTMARKER]Their proposed consent decree included: video and audio recordings of all stops; written documentation with details of the stop; no more dog searches in routine traffic stops; written and oral consent for a search; all asset forfeiture revenue must be donated to nonprofits or used for audio/video equipment or training; and use of an impartial monitor.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree, which it later extended to early 2021 after the plaintiffs alleged noncompliance by the City.

pegasus_output_sents: In 2007, the Inclusive Communities Project (ICP) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) challenging HUD's implementation of the Small Area Fair Market Rent Rule (Small Area FMR Rule) in Dallas, Texas.[SENTMARKER]TheICP alleged that HUD had violated the Fair Housing Act and the Housing and Community Development Act by setting a single FMR based on local, rather than metropolitanwide, prevailing market rents in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, two voucher holders and a nonprofit organization devoted to providing housing opportunities for low-income people in Connecticut, moved to preliminarily enjoin HUD from implementing the rule on January 1, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, finding that HUD lacked the authority to delay the rule’s implementation because it did not observe the requirements of notice and comment, and that the plaintiffs had demonstrated a likelihood of success on the merits as to their arbitrary and capricious claim.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On August 11, 2017, the League of Women Voters of the United States and other plaintiffs filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) in the Eastern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that HUD's two-year delay of the Small Area FMR Rule's implementation was arbitrary and capricious, in contravention of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Fair Market Rents Act (FMR), and that they would suffer irreparable harm if HUD did not implement the Rule by January 1, 2018 .<n>The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the parties filed a motion for attorney's fees and costs due by 3/15.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 18, 2001, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Indiana filed this lawsuit against Edward Rose Development Co LLC and its affiliates.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to include accessible features required by the Fair Housing Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act in a number of apartment complexes it developed in Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, Wisconsin, Illinois and Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree on May 25, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The decree requires the defendants to pay $1,060,000 to a fund for those who may have been harmed by the lack of accessibility features at the complexes.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree will remain in effect for five years.

gold_sents: On June 4, 2013, plaintiffs, natives of Mexico who had agreed to voluntary departure from the United States, filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Central District of California under the Immigration and Nationality Act ("INA"), 8 U.S.C. §1101, and state law against the acting director of Homeland Security, U.S. Customs and Border Protection ("CBP") and Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement ("ICE").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant's agencies in southern California violated INA by coercing plaintiffs into accepting voluntary departure through misstatements, omissions, threats, and/or pressure in violation of defendants' own regulations.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on March 11, 2015, where defendants agreed to allow applications from the class members that would enable their return to the United States and their legal position prior to acceptance of voluntary departure.

pegasus_output_sents: On December 18, 2017, the ACLU of Northern California filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Homeland Security, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking records related to the detention and transport of immigration detainees in the San Francisco area.[SENTMARKER]On April 6, 2018, the ACLU-NC and East Bay Express (EBE), a local independent newspaper, filed a joint FOIA request to ICE seeking records about the 11 transportation immigration detainees and 12 private transportation providers.[SENTMARKER]On September 19, 2019, the court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment and granted the ACLU's motion for injunctive and declaratory relief in the form of a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California (ACLU-NC) filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California on February 6, 2020 .<n>The ACLU-NC sought information and records about contracts with G4S and other private contractors providing transportation services for 7 immigration detainees in the San Francisco area (the "First FOIA Request"), as well as the policies, procedures, and guidelines for detaining and transporting immigration detainees, and records related to the vehicles, officers, and other individuals involved in the transportation process.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered ICE to process and release all responsive records to the FOIA requests, including, but not limited to, the contracts with private contractors 24 for the transport of detainees in San Francisco AOR, the policies and procedures, the detention and transport practices of ICE and its private contractors, and the retention of private transportation providers.[SENTMARKER]In the last case management conference on September 26, 2019, the Court ordered a 19 increase in the size of ICE’s productions from 500 pages per month to 750 pages per monthly.[SENTMARKER]Since 20 then, Defendant has not raised any further issues relating to the scope of Plaintiff’s requests or its 21 ability to meet the increased production requirement.

gold_sents: This case was filed in response to the July 6, 2020 directive by ICE that would effectively force international students studying under F-1 and M-1 visas to attend in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The state of California filed this suit against ICE and DHS on July 9, arguing that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) in two ways.[SENTMARKER]First, the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to take into account students' and universities' reliance interests and the defendants gave no reasoned basis for the new order.[SENTMARKER]Second, the defendants were in violation of procedural elements of the APA, because they failed to use proper notice-and-comment rule-making when issuing the new order.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]California continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 19, 2020.

gold_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents separated from their children filed a civil action against various federal agencies and officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for immediate reunification with their children.The plaintiffs were detained after crossing the United States-Mexico border without inspection with young accompanying children, seeking asylum.[SENTMARKER]After plaintiffs were apprehended at the border, the children were separated under the “zero-tolerance” immigration policy announced April 6, 2018, which criminally prosecuted adult entrants crossing the border illegally and placed accompanying minors in custody of the government.[SENTMARKER]All three plaintiffs crossed the border prior to the Executive Order issued on June 20, 2018, which allowed immigrant parents and children apprehended at the border to remain together during the pendency of their proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged interference of family integrity in violation of Due Process, and sought preliminary and permanent injunctions to immediately reunite plaintiffs with their children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs obtained preliminary relief and were (along with another parent who joined the case later to prevent separation from her daughter) ultimately re-united with their children.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.

gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005; the court also granted the plaintiffs declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Both the state and the city appealed the permanent injunction to the Second Circuit on January 12, 2006, but the city dropped its appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the Second Circuit reversed the district court, ruling that the state did not have a non-delegable duty to administer the decentralized Medicaid and Food Stamp programs, the state’s efforts in supervising the city since the permanent injunction was issued were adequate, and the district court exceeded its authority by issuing a permanent injunction in light of New York State’s affirmative supervisory steps it had taken to assure compliance.[SENTMARKER]In a series of stipulations and orders from January 31, 2007 to July 22, 2011, the City of New York agreed to pay a total of $2,920,675.94 to plaintiffs for attorney fees and costs sought; the state agreed to pay a further $639,918.98.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 12, 2020, the ACLU of Washington filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Washington State Department of Corrections (DOC) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief for a transgender inmate diagnosed with gender dysphoria.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DOC's policy on 16 its face was a blanket policy precluding any gender confirmation surgery for any transgender inmate under any circumstances.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to stay the case for 180 days to allow them to implement the terms of 7 their settlement agreement prior to dismissing the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement in which the DOC will provide gender affirming surgery for Ms. Lotusflower within a reasonable timeframe, within 30 days of receipt of the Evaluator’s written report, within the first two years of her incarceration.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Three indigent persons charged with crimes filed a class action lawsuit in Skagit County Superior Court against the City of Mount Vernon and the City of Burlington alleging defendants failed to provide adequate assistance of counsel.[SENTMARKER]The Cities jointly contracted with two attorneys to handle all public defense assistance cases, and each attorney handled over 1,000 cases per year.[SENTMARKER]The Court found the plaintiffs established their rights were systematically deprived and the Cities were responsible for the deprivation.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief requiring the City of Mount Vernon and City of Burlington re-evaluate their contract for the provision of public defense services and hire one part-time public defense supervisor.
pegasus_output_sents: The City of Mount Vernon and the City of Burlington were sued in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington for violating the Sixth Amendment by failing to protect indigent persons and secure their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to take reasonable steps to protect the defendants' constitutional rights and to provide them with the assistance of counsel for their defense.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the defendants $121,750/year for combined services, or $117,400/year if arraignment is necessary.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 18, 2013 by the Court.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The City of Mount Vernon and the City of Burlington were sued in 2011 by a group of indigent defendants who claimed that the defendants' contract with Sybrandy and Witt allowed each attorney to handle up to 13 l,200 cases per year even though such a caseload is three times the maximum allowable 14 amoWtt for a full-time public defender pursuant to standards established by the Washington 15 State Bar Association.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that defendants had failed to provide adequate funding for their public defense system.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive relief, requiring the defendants to hire more public defenders and pay more for their services.

gold_sents: On November 13, 2018, CNN and CNN’s chief White House correspondent Jim Acosta sued President Trump and several senior members of his administration for violating his First and Fifth Amendment rights by revoking his White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]under The plaintiffs sued under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Declaratory Judgments Act, arguing that defendants violated the Constitution and APA when they revoked Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 13, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, requesting that the court require the defendants to restore Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 16, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case on November 19, 2018 after the Trump administration returned Acosta's White House press credentials to him.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The NAACP and Detroit students and parents sued the Detroit school board and other state defendants in federal court, alleging unconstitutional segregation in Detroit's schools.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that Detroit's schools were illegally segregated, in part because of decisions made by the school board to create and maintain and segregated system.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that a Detroit-only remedy would be insufficient, and ordered a busing plan that would have affected students in city schools and 53 largely white suburban school districts, but the Supreme Court rejected this plan and a Detroit-only remedy was implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 3, 1970, a class of Detroit school children filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the Detroit Board of Education, the State of Michigan, and the Detroit Federation of Teachers.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Detroit School District was segregated on the basis of race and violated the Fourteenth Amendment rights of the children.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for a hearing on its merits.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement in June 1981 to desegregate the Detroit Public Schools and the parties agreed on the amount which the state defendants would contribute to the cost of providing for the educational remedies.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed in part.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 1910, the black population of Detroit, Michigan, was only 1.2% of the total population of the City.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that racial segregation had been imposed in the Detroit city schools.[SENTMARKER]The majority opinion approved the district court's conclusion that a Detroit only integration plan would be insufficient to cure the unconstitutional segregation found to have been imposed.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed in part.
